page.title: 11Derivation of local names.
page.content: COMBE MARTIN takes it's name and crest from Martin de Tours a knight of William 1st who helped in the Conquest and owned the valley in the 11th century. HANGMAN HILL. It is thought that this name is a corruption of the Cornish word "Au" meaning "Boundary" and the Celtic word"Muen" meaning"Stone" COBBLERS PARK. In the 17th century C M was famous for shoemaker's thread made from hemp grown here. KILN CAR PARK. When this car park was constructed one of the best preserved local lime kilns had to be demolished. RIVER UMBER which runs through the village is named after the umber quarried for paint making. CAMELS HEAD looks like one from Seaside Hill.The eye was a mine shaft. CASTLE HILL is reputed to be the site of a Roman camp or castle.
